abstract: Private equity firms are beginning to offer compensation on a previously unimaginable scale to chief executives.
snippet: Private equity firms are beginning to offer compensation on a previously unimaginable scale to chief executives.
lead_paragraph: Robert L. Nardelli’s unceremonious departure from Home Depot may spell the end of the era of super-size pay packages for chief executives of public companies, but a new refuge for lavish compensation and private jets is emerging elsewhere.

headline.main: Private Firms Lure Chief Executives With Top Pay
headline.print_headline: Private Firms Lure C.E.O.’s With Top Pay

byline.original: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Eric Dash

abstract: Robert L. Nardelli’s unceremonious departure from Home Depot may spell the end of the era of super-size pay packages for chief executives of public companies, but a new refuge for lavish compensation is emerging elsewhere. Private equity firms are beginning to offer compensation on a previously unimaginable scale to the chief executives who run the once-public companies that the firms have bought out.
